title: Wall St whistleblower hits jackpot. More to follow?
text:
One thing to start: one of Royal Dutch Shell's biggest shareholders has dismissed the activist hedge fund Third Point's proposal to split the oil major into separate companies, saying it would be too complicated and unlikely to add value for long-term investors.

When standing up to Wall Street pays off big

A private island in Palm Beach, Florida, or 10 Bugatti Voiture Noires.

That is what the record-busting $200m whistleblower reward announced by the Commodity Futures Trading Commission last week can buy.

So it's no wonder the payout to the former Deutsche Bank employee, whose complaints led to a record $2.5bn in fines in the US and the UK to settle allegations that the bank manipulated the Libor benchmark rate, had heads turning on Wall Street.

Experts have told the FT's Stefania Palma and Joshua Franklin any high-profile award tends to spark fresh rounds of tips.

It happened in 2018, when three Bank of America employees were given $83m in awards in a case of misconduct at the broker-dealer arm of Merrill Lynch. The Securities and Exchange Commission received 5,282 tips that year, up almost 20 per cent from 2017.

Bradley Birkenfeld, a former UBS banker who was awarded $104m in 2012 through the IRS's whistleblower programme and fields calls from potential whistleblowers looking for advice, said he thinks “there'll be a lot of people coming out of the woodwork trying to think, ‘Hey, I've got that next big case'”.

It's true that rewards are getting bigger and US whistleblower programmes are busier as longstanding probes that may have started at the beginning of these schemes, established by the Dodd-Frank Act a decade ago, come to a head.

But bankers who may have suddenly found a higher moral calling would do well to manage their expectations — most rewards still sit in the single or double digit million range. The CFTC's $200m award was almost seven times larger than its second-biggest payout of $30m in 2018.

Perhaps unsurprisingly, a New York bank questioned whether the $200m cheque would lead to more cases that wouldn't otherwise have been reported.

But past trends in tip numbers and the commotion caused by this mega payment could tell another story. It might just be that future whistleblowers with high-quality complaints end up affording just one Bugatti Voiture Noire, instead of 10. Boo hoo.

What T Rowe's big move into alternatives means

A major investor in private markets will be going public . . . sort of.

T Rowe Price is buying Oak Hill Advisors, a $53bn in assets manager of private debt investments for $3.3bn in cash and stock, with the potential for earn outs to increase the value to $4.2bn.

The deal is a watershed for T Rowe, a Baltimore-based investment firm led by Bill Stromberg that is synonymous with mutual funds and defined contribution retirement plans.

In Oak Hill, it's moving into uncharted territory, buying a savvy investor in complex debts that had early backing from Robert Bass, one of four brothers who founded Bass Brothers Enterprises, a feared corporate raider in the 1980s. 

Oak Hill, a firm led by Glenn August, is among several fast-growing private debt investment firms that are the new centre of power in credit markets.

Like competitors Sixth Street and HPS Investment Management, and large public alternative asset managers Ares, Apollo Global and Blackstone, Oak Hill specialises in illiquid debt investments such as direct loans to buyout firms, structured securities and real asset strategies.

These benefit from a “illiquidity premium” and the sheer complexity of assets such as collateralised loan obligations and other securitisations. Meanwhile, it's been a brutal environment for liquid corporate and sovereign debt markets, where yields continue to fall towards zero.

The acquisition signals T Rowe's intention to expand into alternatives, particularly as they are opened to retail and high-net worth investors. But there are only a few traditional asset managers with the brand or financial resources to pivot into private markets.

The mutual fund firms Franklin Resources, Janus Henderson and AllianceBernstein once traded at premiums to alternative firms but now carry steep discounts. Some, such as Legg Mason and Eaton Vance, have given up on public markets and sold out.

The wild card potential acquirer is BlackRock, which is a backer of the alternative fund provider iCapital, underscoring its interest in the asset class.

If BlackRock's Larry Fink does use its stock as currency to acquire a private equity or debt firm, it will be a turning of the tables for a group that won early backing from Blackstone, the world's largest alternative manager.

Job moves

  • The law firm Latham & Watkins has named 44 new partners.

  • Longtime Freshfields partner Matthew Herman is joining Goldfinch Partners, a US-based private equity firm, where he will be a partner and general counsel. He will be based in New York and begins next month.

  • The law firm Shearman & Sterling has hired Xavier Norlain, Jeremy Scemama, Maud Manon and Matthieu Lampel as partners from DLA Piper in Paris.

  • Brunswick Group has recruited Andrew Williams and Errol Cockfield as partners in its New York office. Williams joins from Goldman Sachs and Cockfield moves from MSNBC.
